Rinchem's technicians and supervisors attend annual emergency action plan refreshers where tabletop drills are performed, and facility orientation classes are held where evacuation plans and procedures are reviewed. Facility-wide drills are also performed.

1.6 PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY

Rinchem believes that no changes are necessary at this time to address improvement to safety at our facilities. Rinchem's procedures, safety policies, facility design and many other preventative measures are adequate to keep its employees, the community and the environment safe. However, we are committed to continue working our corrective action process to monitor and improve the safety of all operations.

tion to training and safety.
The areas of compliance include:
- having an OSHA Process Safety Management Plan for Hydroxylamine solution at the facility
- only accepting materials that are in Department of Transportation-approved containers
- segregating materials according to their hazard class
- having secondary and tertiary containment inside the building and around the facility
- limiting access to the facility
- performance of daily inspections of the material handling equipment used in the facility

Before hydrochloric acid 37% solution, hydrofluoric acid 50%, ammonia 20%, or tetramethylsilane is accepted into the warehouse, the trailer they are brought in is visually checked for any leaks out away from the dock area. During the unloading the containers are checked for any sign of leakage or damage, if damage is found it's reported to the supervisor or Manager to verify containers is safe for storage. The facility is inspected daily to ensure that all operations are running safely and smoothly and to determine if any of the containers in storage are leaking. It is Rinchem's policy that any time a release is detected, the supervisor is notified to report to the emergency coordinator, who follows chain of command to  immediately notify outside emergency response to properly respond to incidents.

Training is an essential element of Rinchem's prevention program since an informed and trained workforce can prevent most accidents. The training includes on-the-job and computer based training for all new employees as well as annual reviews of the operating procedures with the employees and supervisors who perform the tasks at the facility.

1.4 FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY
There has never been a reportable accident involving regulated substances at this facility.

1.5 EMERGENCY RESPONSE PLAN

Rinchem has a comprehensive emergency action plan. The plan includes evacuation and notification procedures for the employees of Rinchem and for the public. The facility is include

1.0 Executive Summary

1.1 ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES

Rinchem Company, LLC. (Rinchem) is totally committed to safety and the implementation of safe procedures. Its commitment is exemplified by its overall safety policy which states:
No job is more important than the health and safety of our employees, our communities and the environment.

This policy is supported by everyone at Rinchem, but first and foremost by senior management.

1.2 THE FACILITY AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLED

Rinchem's Hillsboro Chemical Warehouse at 5650 N.E. Huffman Hillsboro, Oregon, stores chemicals for industry. The following substances regulated under 40 CFR part 68 are, or intend to be stored above the threshold quantity at this facility: Hydrochloric acid 37% or greater, hydrofluoric acid 50% or greater, ammonia 20% or greater, and tetramethylsilane. The chemical substances are not involved with any processes at this location other than handling and storage of closed containers.
Rinchem is located in an isolated urban industrial setting with very few nearby residential neighbors. The Hillsboro Warehouse was built taking into consideration fire codes, building codes and industry standards for warehouses that store hazardous materials. There are many features designed into the building that help to prevent a liquid release of any of the stored substances to the environment such as secondary containment at the docks and berms in the rooms where the materials are stored. Flammable materials are stored separately in rooms classified for flammable materials storage. The materials in the warehouse are segregated by hazard class according to the applicable federal and state regulations.

1.3 GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM AND CHEMICAL-SPECIFIC PREVENTION STEPS
